sections.title: The Security of Those Who Fear the Lord

verses.text: No evil will befall the one who fears the Lord, but in temptation, he will be delivered again and again.
verses.comment: This verse connects fear of the Lord with protection from evil, echoing the assurance found in Psalm 91. The idea that God delivers the righteous foreshadows divine protection seen in the New Testament.
verses.sectionHeader: The Security of Those Who Fear the Lord

verses.text: A wise person will not hate the law, but the hypocrite is like a boat in a storm.
verses.comment: Love for God’s law is contrasted with the instability of the hypocrite. The comparison to a boat in a storm reminds us of Christ calming the sea and the need for anchoring in God's truth.

verses.text: A person of understanding trusts in the law, and the law is faithful to him as an inquiry.
verses.comment: The law here references God’s revealed instruction, foreshadowing the fulfillment of the law in Christ (see Matt 5:17).

verses.text: Prepare your words, then you will be listened to; draw upon what you have learned, and you will be answered.
verses.comment: This verse encourages prudent speech and study, an idea also found in Proverbs. It points to the importance of tradition and teaching in communicating truth.

verses.text: The inner thoughts of the foolish are like a cart wheel, and their imagination revolves like an axle.
verses.comment: Foolishness is portrayed as pointless movement; wisdom brings direction and stability.

verses.text: A mocking friend is like a stallion that neighs no matter who rides him.
verses.comment: The unreliability of mockers is compared to an untamed horse. This shows the need for wise and faithful companions.

verses.text: Why is one day more important than another, though the light of every day in the year comes from the sun?
verses.comment: Questions about the difference in days hint at later practices regarding holy days and appointed times for worship.

verses.text: By the Lord’s knowledge they were distinguished, and he appointed different seasons and feasts.
verses.comment: God's authority to set times for feasts points to the sacred order established by Him, underlying the importance of a liturgical calendar.

verses.text: Some of them he exalted and sanctified, and some of them he made ordinary days.
verses.comment: The distinction between holy and ordinary times shows God’s authority to establish sacred things, a theme fulfilled in Christ and continued in apostolic practice.

verses.text: All human beings come from dust, and from the earth Adam was created.
verses.comment: This recalls Genesis, the unity of mankind’s origin. The new Adam, Christ, later re-unites a divided humanity.

verses.text: But with great knowledge the Lord distinguished them and assigned different paths.
verses.comment: God’s providence assigns varied roles and destinies within humanity, reflecting His sovereignty and wisdom.

verses.text: Some he blessed and exalted, and some he made holy and drew near to himself. But others he cursed and humbled, and expelled from their place.
verses.comment: The spiritual hierarchy among people is a result of God’s choosing—this underlies the idea of being set apart for sacred purposes.

verses.text: Like clay in the hand of the potter, to be shaped as he decides, so are people in the hand of their Maker, who gives them as he judges best.
verses.comment: God’s sovereignty as potter is echoed in Isaiah and Paul, indicating both personal vocation and collective destinies.

verses.text: Good is opposed to evil, and life is opposed to death; so also is the sinner opposed to the godly.
verses.comment: The contrast of good and evil prefigures later teachings about spiritual warfare and the two ways.

verses.text: So look at all the works of the Most High: they come in pairs, one the opposite of the other.
verses.comment: This highlights creation’s order and the moral realities of the human condition, fulfilled in Christ as the new creation.

verses.text: Now I was the last to keep watch; like one who gathers the gleanings after the grape pickers.
verses.comment: The author positions himself humbly, gathering the final wisdom much like Ruth gleaned after the harvesters.

verses.text: By the blessing of the Lord I have gained the firstfruits of knowledge, and I am advancing to teach others as well.
verses.comment: Humility in receiving and transmitting wisdom mirrors the apostolic ministry to hand on the faith.

verses.text: Consider that I have not labored for myself alone, but for all who seek instruction.
verses.comment: Teaching is for the benefit of the whole community, emphasizing the value of shared tradition.

verses.text: Listen to me, you princes of the people, and you rulers of the assembly, pay attention!
verses.comment: A call to leaders to receive wisdom, as echoed in Moses’ address to Israel’s elders.

verses.text: Do not give your son, wife, brother, or friend power over you during your lifetime, and do not give your property away, lest you regret it and have to beg for it again.
verses.comment: Practical financial wisdom, warning against the surrender of stewardship and responsibility.

verses.text: As long as you live and have breath in you, do not give your inheritance to anyone.
verses.comment: Retaining one’s inheritance is presented as wise stewardship, ensuring future provision.

verses.text: It is better for your children to ask from you than for you to look to their hands.
verses.comment: Parental responsibility and foresight reflect the larger principle of charity and provision.

verses.text: Keep control over all that you do, and do not stain your honor.
verses.comment: Maintaining one’s reputation is closely associated with virtue and honor, linked to Christian witness.

verses.text: When the days of your life are ending, at the time of death, distribute your inheritance.
verses.comment: The proper timing for bequeathing one’s goods follows the wisdom tradition of Israel.

verses.text: Fodder, the rod, and burdens are for the donkey; bread, discipline, and work are for a servant.
verses.comment: This reflects the social order of the time, recognizing the dignity of work and appropriate discipline.

verses.text: Set your servant to work, and you will find rest; let his hands be idle, and he will seek freedom.
verses.comment: Hard work is seen as beneficial, both for master and servant. See Paul’s analogy of spiritual slavery to righteousness (Rom 6:18).

verses.text: Yoke and strap will bow a hard neck, and force and discipline are continually for a wicked servant.
verses.comment: Discipline for those resistant to instruction is a persistent theme in wisdom literature.

verses.text: Send him to work, so he will not be idle; for idleness teaches much evil.
verses.comment: Idleness as the root of sin is also a theme in Christian admonitions. Discipline forms character.

verses.text: Assign him to work that is proper for him, and if he does not obey, increase his shackles.
verses.comment: This verse reflects ancient approaches to managing servants or slaves, emphasizing discipline and appropriate tasks to maintain order; it also reveals Sirach's pragmatic rather than an idealistic view of social hierarchy (cf. Colossians 4:1), highlighting the importance of just and fitting treatment within a household.

verses.text: But do not be overbearing toward anyone, and do nothing without justice.
verses.comment: The link of compassion and justice moderates discipline and reflects Christ’s teaching of charity.

verses.text: If you have a servant, let him be as yourself, because you have bought him with blood.
verses.comment: The principle of treating servants with dignity parallels Christ’s purchasing of believers with his own blood.

verses.text: If you have a servant, treat him as a brother, for you need him as you need yourself.
verses.comment: Brotherly treatment of those who serve anticipates the Christian call to mutual love and unity.

verses.text: If you harm him and he escapes and runs away, which way will you go to search for him?
verses.comment: Mistreatment of others leads to loss and shame, pointing to the biblical principle of justice for all.
